channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Live in sunny Oxford, walk to work along the canal, squeaky clean codebase
item.description: Friendly and Perl-committed company based in Oxford who build a very popular software product. They use Catalyst + Starman, DBIx::Class, and are heavily bought in to Moose. Despite having been running for many years, almost none of the code is older than 3 years after a successful ground-up rewrite.

item.title: Work with giant, caged robots, and Perl; Senior Developer, West London
item.description: Letâ€™s start off talking about the robots. They live in cages, they travel at 60mph, and theyâ€™re controlled via AMQ messages from a Perl-based Warehouse Management System. Simultaneously awesome and terrifying, they work tirelessly to move expensive dresses around such exotic locations as Charlton, and Mahwah,New Jersey...

item.title: Come work for Zoopla, one of London's success stories
item.description: Zoopla are one of Londonâ€™s top technical companies; theyâ€™re a household name with beautiful offices on Londonâ€™s Southbank, and founded by theÂ same people behind another of Londonâ€™s tech success stories LOVEFiLM.

item.title: Swiss Perl Workshop
item.description: September 7-8, 2018 Bern.

item.title: The Perl Conference in Europe
item.description: August 15-17, 2018, Glasgow. The Call for Papers is open.

item.title: NLPW - Dutch Perl Workshop 2018
item.description: July 7, 2018, Arnhem, The Netherlands

item.title: The Perl Conference in North America
item.description: June 17-22, 2018, Salt Lake City.

item.title: French Perl Workshop
item.description: May 18-19, 2018, Paris.

item.title: A decade of classes in Lausanne
item.description: May 14-18, 2018, Lausanne. Five training classes by Damian.

item.title: Presentation Aikido
item.description: May 8-9, 2018, Budapest. Presentation Aikido by Damian and lots of other workshop at the Craft Conference.

item.title: Profiling part of a Perl application
item.description: An example using Devel::NYTProf

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: What's the Value of CI/CD?
item.description: There are 2 questions: 'Can we ship?' and 'Should we ship?' - There are 3 XP practices that help you answer the former: Stories, TDD, and Continuous Integration. The articles cover these topics and why do they matter. (seen in Devops Weekly)

item.title: Linux Journal March Issue
item.description:
I've just received an e-mail from Linux Journal, (I am subscribed to their free newsletter), with a link to the previous issue. It starts with an interesting article on the evils of visitor tracking and targeted advertising and how they will try to set an example on a better way to created content.
There is also an article titled 'Blockchain: Introduction and Cryptocurrency. Configuring a Blockchain Network and Leveraging the Technology.'
There is also an article about ZFS for Linux.

item.title: Want to be a developer? You should probably be Pair Programming.
item.description: A slightly funny, slightly strange explanation of what is Pair programming and why it can be good for your career. Including several Pair-programming techniques you can try. Let me know if you'd like to try pair programming either with me or with some other Perl developer. Let's see where does this lead us?

item.title: My 'Go for Perl Hackers' Cheatsheet
item.description: Can be found here.

item.title: 2018.15 Perkenalan Bahasa Pemrograman Perl 6
item.description: The weekly dose of Perl 6 news.

item.title: StackOverflow that!
item.description: JJ suggests that instead of keeping the technical question and answers confined to the IRC channel of Perl 6 people should post them to Stack Overflow as well as it is a better place for storing questions and answers. Posting the questions and answers on SO is better than just keeping them in an IRC conversation, but I think it would be way better to put them on the Perl 6 site or in the Perl 6 documentation. If necessary, put some effort to make those sites more SEO friendly, but IMHO it is better to keep the valuable content on the site related to the project that to hand it over to a third party.

item.title: blead Breaks CPAN a.k.a. BBC
item.description: The toolchain summit 2018 in Oslo, Norway is a good opportunity to improve the tools to measure the risks involved in changes made to Perl.

item.title: A new wobbly wheel for GUIDeFATE
item.description: GUIDeFATE stands for 'Graphical User Interface Design From A Text Editor'. It enables the user to convert a textual representation into a Graphical user Interface.

item.title: Refurbished App::DBBrowser
item.description: <a href="https://metacpan.org/pod/App::DBBrowser"> allows you to browse SQLite, MySQL, and PostgreSQL databases and their tables interactively.

item.title: Curious about Perl's strengths in 2018
item.description: Some points if you need help convincing someone to use Perl, and some other points if you'd like to say when some other language might be preferable. Even if not for technical reasons.

item.title: A Guide to Versions in Perl
item.description: Giving version numbers to your project, or understanding the versioning scheme of another project is important as it can communicate a lot of information to both humans and tools that need to compare versions. This article goes over the two ways to write version numbers in Perl and provides you with all the information you'll need.

item.title: WWW::Mechanize Best Practices
item.description: A few pitfalls in WWW::Mechanize caused by defaults that you might, or might not expect to be what they are. Olaf has some excellent suggestions that already mad it to the official documentation as well, but they are worth pointing out separately as well.

item.title: #351 - What would you like to read about?
item.description:
Hello there!

For a long time I have not been logging the clicks on the Perl Weekly links, so I have no idea which of the subjects are interesting to you. Moreover I cannot know if there are subjects that would be interesting but are not usually covered. So speak up! Let me know (in an e-mail), what are the topics you are most interested in. What would you like to see covered in the Perl Weekly?

BTW thank you for your support! The Programming the Raspberry Pi with Perl crowdfunding campaign already has 89 backers providing $2,115 which is 85% of the goal.

Have a nice week!
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
